title: CDB provides US$20 million syndicated loans to the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' (Linked to Project ID#69997, #40482, #40479, #40481)
description: On May 20, 2013, several loan agreements between the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk" and China Development Bank of China (CDB) were signed. The USD portion of the 5 agreements totaled to USD 20 million, however no breakdown of the individual agreements was found.   The loans were part of a series of investments made on May 20th during President of Tajikistan Emomalii Rahmon's visit to China. These other projects were: loans totalling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement.
staff_comments: A single listed source (https://amonatbonk.tj/tj/about/news/2757/) discusses an 8.5 million USD loan. It is possible that this may be a single loan among the many that were wrapped into this 20 million USD aggregate, but there is no confirmation for this.
combined_text:
# Sector
BANKING AND FINANCIAL SERVICES

# Title
CDB provides US$20 million syndicated loans to the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan 'Amonatbonk' (Linked to Project ID#69997, #40482, #40479, #40481)

# Description
On May 20, 2013, several loan agreements between the State Savings Bank of Tajikistan "Amonatbonk" and China Development Bank of China (CDB) were signed. The USD portion of the 5 agreements totaled to USD 20 million, however no breakdown of the individual agreements was found.   The loans were part of a series of investments made on May 20th during President of Tajikistan Emomalii Rahmon's visit to China. These other projects were: loans totalling 33 million RMB to Amonatbonk (captured in project ID#69997), a 200 million RMB grant (captured in project ID#40481), an agreement for the reconstruction of Regar Substation (captured in project ID#40482), a loan to Zijin Mining for investment into the Zeravshan Gold Mine (captured in project ID#40479), a technical cooperation agreement, a fruit inspection protocol, and a sports cooperation agreement.
justification: Project involves financial services with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Syndicated loans provided to State Savings Bank of Tajikistan, no specific environmental or energy-related components mentioned

title: Chinese Ministry of Public Security provides RMB 20 million grant for police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers
description: In 2013, the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China provided a grant worth RMB 20 million to the Government of Tajikistan for the provision of police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers to Tajikistan’s Ministry of the Interior, Narcotics Administration and National Security Commission. The police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers were officially delivered to the local authorities on or around November 21, 2013.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Public Security provides RMB 20 million grant for police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers

# Description
In 2013, the Ministry of Public Security of the People's Republic of China provided a grant worth RMB 20 million to the Government of Tajikistan for the provision of police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers to Tajikistan’s Ministry of the Interior, Narcotics Administration and National Security Commission. The police patrol cars, police communications equipment, and computers were officially delivered to the local authorities on or around November 21, 2013.
justification: Project focuses on law enforcement equipment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of police patrol cars, communications equipment, and computers for law enforcement purposes

title: China Donates Sewing Machines and bikes for Zanzibar Women's Group
description: In February 2013, the wife of Chinese Ambassador, Ms. Mao Xiaoqiu, donated 20 sewing machines and 20 bicycles to women's groups in Zanzibar. The donation is directed to support women through skills building and vocational training for self employment opportunities. The bicycles will help women travel around the island for work or errands. The donation is estimated at 8 million Tanzanian shillings.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Donates Sewing Machines and bikes for Zanzibar Women's Group

# Description
In February 2013, the wife of Chinese Ambassador, Ms. Mao Xiaoqiu, donated 20 sewing machines and 20 bicycles to women's groups in Zanzibar. The donation is directed to support women through skills building and vocational training for self employment opportunities. The bicycles will help women travel around the island for work or errands. The donation is estimated at 8 million Tanzanian shillings.
justification: Project focuses on social development and women's empowerment without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of sewing machines and bicycles for women's groups, focus on skills building and vocational training

title: China funds and builds the Tanzania-Chinese Cultural Center in Dar es Salaam
description: In March 2013, during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Tanzania, both parties agreed to establish the Tanzania-Chinese Cultural Center (or 坦桑尼亚中国文化中心) in Dar es Salaam. The Chinese government likely financed this project with a grant but it is unclear how much.   The Tanzania Chinese Cultural Center is the first cultural center established by the Chinese government in East Africa for the purposes of China-Tanzania cultural exchanges. The new center will be able to accommodate 100-120 students at a time. Discussions on how to implement the project began in April 2013, and the Tanzania Cultural Center was inaugurated on December 1, 2015 following a trial operation on September 29, 2015.
staff_comments: This project is separate from another cultural center captured in project #68492
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China funds and builds the Tanzania-Chinese Cultural Center in Dar es Salaam

# Description
In March 2013, during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Tanzania, both parties agreed to establish the Tanzania-Chinese Cultural Center (or 坦桑尼亚中国文化中心) in Dar es Salaam. The Chinese government likely financed this project with a grant but it is unclear how much.   The Tanzania Chinese Cultural Center is the first cultural center established by the Chinese government in East Africa for the purposes of China-Tanzania cultural exchanges. The new center will be able to accommodate 100-120 students at a time. Discussions on how to implement the project began in April 2013, and the Tanzania Cultural Center was inaugurated on December 1, 2015 following a trial operation on September 29, 2015.
justification: Cultural center focused on cultural exchange and education, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Tanzania-Chinese Cultural Center, focus on cultural exchanges and education, capacity for 100-120 students

title: China Eximbank provides $93.77 million loan for Phase III (Sub-Phase I) of the Tanzania National Fiber Optic Backbone Project (Linked to Project ID#23142, #23150)
description: On September 30, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed a $70 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase I of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. The loan, which via captured via Project ID#23142, carried an interest rate of 1% but its maturity and grace period are unknown. Then, in 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed an RMB 700 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase II of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. This loan carried a 1% interest rate. Its maturity and grace period are unknown. Then, on March 25, 2013, China Eximbank and Bank of Tanzania signed a loan agreement worth $93.77 million for Phase III (Sub-Phase I) of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. The loan, which is captured via Project ID#30603, carried a 1% interest rate. Its maturity and grace period are unknown.   Huawei Technologies and China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation (CITCC) (a subsidiary of China Telecom) were the implementing contractors for the project's three phases.   The entire backbone project was intended to cover 10,674 km. Tanzania Telecommunications Co Ltd (TTCL) was mandated to manage the National Fiber Optic Backbone. It was also designed to connect to the international submarine cables of EASSY & SEACOM through cross-border connectivity -- namely Kenya (at two points of Sirari na Namanga), Uganda (at Mutukula), Rwanda (at Rusumo), Malawi (at Kasumulo), Burundi (at Kabanga) and Zambia (at Tunduma).  The first phase covered 7,000 kilometers over northern and eastern Tanzania in cities like Dar es Salaam to Tanga, Moshi, Arusha, Singida, Dodoma, Iringa, and Morogoro and provide connections to Rwanda, Burundi (Manyovu), Uganda, and Kenya (Horohoro). Phase 1 ultimately laid 4,330 km of cable; 2,280 km of which was part of a newly built Optic Fibre Cable (OFC) network and 2,050 km of which was part of an existing OFC network from TANESCO. It started on July 24, 2009 and completed May 29, 2010.  The second phase was designed to be 3,674 kilometers and link Dar es Salaam to Kigoma, Taborak, Sumbawanga, Mbeya, Songea, Mtwara, and Lindi in Tanzania as well as Zambia and Malawi. Phase II of the project ultimately laid 3,230 km of cable; 3,168 km of which was part of a newly built OFC network and 62 km of which was part of the existing OFC network from TANESCO. The second phase was supposed to increase connectivity to rural villages and reduce costs by approximately 80%. The second phase officially began on August 1, 2010 and completed on October 21, 2015.  Phase III involved the expansion of the existing NICTBB network by connecting Zanzibar and Pemba to the NICTBB, establishing a full-mesh Internet Protocol layer Multiprotocol Label Switching (IP-MPLS) to the existing Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM) and Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) layers, as well as building a data center in Dar es Salaam. Works officially began on June 27, 2015, ended in June 2016, and the NICTBB was made operational in September 2016.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 国家骨干光纤网项目.2. This project is also known as Phase 3 of the National ICT Fiber Backbone Project (NICTBB) or National ICT Broad Infrastructure Project.3. The loan's interest rate is drawn from the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (see https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0).
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Eximbank provides $93.77 million loan for Phase III (Sub-Phase I) of the Tanzania National Fiber Optic Backbone Project (Linked to Project ID#23142, #23150)

# Description
On September 30, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed a $70 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase I of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. The loan, which via captured via Project ID#23142, carried an interest rate of 1% but its maturity and grace period are unknown. Then, in 2010, China Eximbank and the Government of Tanzania signed an RMB 700 million government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for Phase II of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. This loan carried a 1% interest rate. Its maturity and grace period are unknown. Then, on March 25, 2013, China Eximbank and Bank of Tanzania signed a loan agreement worth $93.77 million for Phase III (Sub-Phase I) of the National Fiber Optic Backbone Project. The loan, which is captured via Project ID#30603, carried a 1% interest rate. Its maturity and grace period are unknown.   Huawei Technologies and China International Telecommunication Construction Corporation (CITCC) (a subsidiary of China Telecom) were the implementing contractors for the project's three phases.   The entire backbone project was intended to cover 10,674 km. Tanzania Telecommunications Co Ltd (TTCL) was mandated to manage the National Fiber Optic Backbone. It was also designed to connect to the international submarine cables of EASSY & SEACOM through cross-border connectivity -- namely Kenya (at two points of Sirari na Namanga), Uganda (at Mutukula), Rwanda (at Rusumo), Malawi (at Kasumulo), Burundi (at Kabanga) and Zambia (at Tunduma).  The first phase covered 7,000 kilometers over northern and eastern Tanzania in cities like Dar es Salaam to Tanga, Moshi, Arusha, Singida, Dodoma, Iringa, and Morogoro and provide connections to Rwanda, Burundi (Manyovu), Uganda, and Kenya (Horohoro). Phase 1 ultimately laid 4,330 km of cable; 2,280 km of which was part of a newly built Optic Fibre Cable (OFC) network and 2,050 km of which was part of an existing OFC network from TANESCO. It started on July 24, 2009 and completed May 29, 2010.  The second phase was designed to be 3,674 kilometers and link Dar es Salaam to Kigoma, Taborak, Sumbawanga, Mbeya, Songea, Mtwara, and Lindi in Tanzania as well as Zambia and Malawi. Phase II of the project ultimately laid 3,230 km of cable; 3,168 km of which was part of a newly built OFC network and 62 km of which was part of the existing OFC network from TANESCO. The second phase was supposed to increase connectivity to rural villages and reduce costs by approximately 80%. The second phase officially began on August 1, 2010 and completed on October 21, 2015.  Phase III involved the expansion of the existing NICTBB network by connecting Zanzibar and Pemba to the NICTBB, establishing a full-mesh Internet Protocol layer Multiprotocol Label Switching (IP-MPLS) to the existing Dense Wavelength Division Multiplexing (DWDM) and Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) layers, as well as building a data center in Dar es Salaam. Works officially began on June 27, 2015, ended in June 2016, and the NICTBB was made operational in September 2016.
justification: Project focuses on telecommunications infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Fiber optic backbone development, data center construction, telecommunications network expansion

title: China Donates Television Broadcasting Truck to Tanzania Broadcasting Corporation
description: In the March 2013 package agreements signed between China and Tanzania, there was an exchange of letters for the donation of a television broadcast truck to the Tanzania Broadcasting Corporation. The agreement was signed between Tanzanian Minister for Finance, William Mgimwa, and the Chinese Minister of Commerce. The truck was handed over on 2014 June 26, and was presented by the visiting Chinese Vice-President Li Yuanchao during a ceremony attended by the Tanzanian Minister of Information Dr Fenela Mukangara.
combined_text:
# Sector
COMMUNICATIONS

# Title
China Donates Television Broadcasting Truck to Tanzania Broadcasting Corporation

# Description
In the March 2013 package agreements signed between China and Tanzania, there was an exchange of letters for the donation of a television broadcast truck to the Tanzania Broadcasting Corporation. The agreement was signed between Tanzanian Minister for Finance, William Mgimwa, and the Chinese Minister of Commerce. The truck was handed over on 2014 June 26, and was presented by the visiting Chinese Vice-President Li Yuanchao during a ceremony attended by the Tanzanian Minister of Information Dr Fenela Mukangara.
justification: Project involves donation of broadcasting equipment for media purposes, unrelated to energy or environmental impact
evidence: Television broadcasting truck donation, communications sector focus

title: China Provides Shipping Container Inspection Equipment to Tanzania
description: In the March 2013 infrastructure deals signed by China and Tanzania, the two governments exchanged letters on the provision of a set of shipping container inspection equipment to be given to the port of Zanzibar. On September 9th, Tanzania's Minister of Finance, Mr. Omar Sang, and a representative of the Chinese government signed off on the final exchange. As of September 9, 2013, one scanner worth $3.6 million USD was handed over to Zanzibar authorities.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRADE POLICIES AND REGULATIONS

# Title
China Provides Shipping Container Inspection Equipment to Tanzania

# Description
In the March 2013 infrastructure deals signed by China and Tanzania, the two governments exchanged letters on the provision of a set of shipping container inspection equipment to be given to the port of Zanzibar. On September 9th, Tanzania's Minister of Finance, Mr. Omar Sang, and a representative of the Chinese government signed off on the final exchange. As of September 9, 2013, one scanner worth $3.6 million USD was handed over to Zanzibar authorities.
justification: Project involves provision of inspection equipment for trade purposes, with no clear environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Shipping container inspection equipment, trade-related infrastructure

title: China funds and builds phase I of the Zanzibar Water Supply Project (Linked to #60108)
description: In March 2013, the Chinese government agreed to grant funds and build phase I of the Zanzibar Water Supply Project (or 桑给巴尔第一期打井供水项目). The value of this project is unknown. China also financed phase II (project #60108).   The purpose of this project was to help Zanzibar improve its water facilities and services. Phase I involved the construction of water wells, a new water plant, and four water supply stations in five areas (Chaani, Donge, Kisongoni, Kiboje, and Miwani) on Unguja Island.  Beijing Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Project construction began on June 18, 2016 and ended on January 3, 2019.
combined_text:
# Sector
WATER SUPPLY AND SANITATION

# Title
China funds and builds phase I of the Zanzibar Water Supply Project (Linked to #60108)

# Description
In March 2013, the Chinese government agreed to grant funds and build phase I of the Zanzibar Water Supply Project (or 桑给巴尔第一期打井供水项目). The value of this project is unknown. China also financed phase II (project #60108).   The purpose of this project was to help Zanzibar improve its water facilities and services. Phase I involved the construction of water wells, a new water plant, and four water supply stations in five areas (Chaani, Donge, Kisongoni, Kiboje, and Miwani) on Unguja Island.  Beijing Construction Engineering Group was the contractor responsible for project implementation. Project construction began on June 18, 2016 and ended on January 3, 2019.
justification: Project focuses on water supply infrastructure without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of water wells, water plant, and supply stations for water facilities improvement

title: China establishes Confucius Institute at the University of Dar es Salaam (Linked to #60628)
description: On January 17, 2013 an agreement was signed for the establishment of a Confucius Institute at the University of Dar es Salaam. The Chinese governmental organization responsible for this project is Hanban. The value of this project is unknown.   The Chinese institution that was paired with the University of Dar es Salaam for this project is Zhejiang Normal University. This project was completed in 2013 and the institute began operating October 9, 2013. The institute offers courses in Chinese, summer camps, kung fu and taiji classes and Chinese culture events.   The Confucius Institute was later renovated in 2016 and moved to the new China-funded library (#60628)
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China establishes Confucius Institute at the University of Dar es Salaam (Linked to #60628)

# Description
On January 17, 2013 an agreement was signed for the establishment of a Confucius Institute at the University of Dar es Salaam. The Chinese governmental organization responsible for this project is Hanban. The value of this project is unknown.   The Chinese institution that was paired with the University of Dar es Salaam for this project is Zhejiang Normal University. This project was completed in 2013 and the institute began operating October 9, 2013. The institute offers courses in Chinese, summer camps, kung fu and taiji classes and Chinese culture events.   The Confucius Institute was later renovated in 2016 and moved to the new China-funded library (#60628)
justification: Project focuses on cultural and educational exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute offering language and cultural courses, no energy-related components mentioned
